boardgame.name: Ruins of Vohenheim
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Tight cobblestone streets lined with rubble and fresh snow lie in the shadows of the tall broken buildings that crisscross above. A small church sits quietly across the street from a tavern where travelers once stopped to dine on exotic sausages and ale.

The second level of the city consists of a large stone bridge which passes over the alleyways and more dangerous shadowy locations that the lower city consists of. The old tavern continues to rise here which gave more space to guests and rooms where they could sleep. Across the stone bridge are more houses that lie broken and forgotten.

The top floor of the tavern consists of a large room now overgrown by nature, while the other buildings have small rooms which consist of rubble and broken windows.

boardgame.name: Pirate's Secret Cove
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Gentle waves crash against the rocky shore of the cavern filling the inner chambers with the salty scent of the sea. Stone steps that have been carved out over the ages lead up into two chambers containing tables with wine and gold as well as hammocks for sleeping and several small chests containing treasures that were perhaps claimed against their previous owners wishes.

Further on a corridor holds a small room bared by iron, inside some hay and cloth form a makeshift bed for any prisoners that may be captured. Finally you reach the main chamber where feasting and loud laughing go on while the inhabitants of this cave work on their next plan.

Adventure Seed

You’ve been tasked by the city guard to investigate and shut down a smuggling ring which is responsible for bringing in and distributing a substance that has recently become illegal. The drug has been connected with a string of violent incidents and a marginal increase in indecent exposure.

The city guard is unable to inform you to exact nature of the substance but those who have been caught using it call it “Red Devil” and have been found in the sleazier parts of the city.

When you manage to track the smugglers to a small cove just outside the city. You’re meet by a merry band of men celebrating within a cavern who are quick to draw their swords when you approach.

Inside the barrels you find the so called drug... fermented crab meat!

Further into the cave you also come across a man in rags locked in a cell. He begs for you to let him out, explaining that he was in charge of the importing of the fermented crab meat but when it was banned he decided to hire on some smugglers as the profit was to good to give up. However when the smugglers he had hired figured out they could run the entire operation themselves they threw him into a cell.

What is going on? A powerful merchant who had previously cornered the market on exotic aphrodisiacs, was shocked when his products stopped selling. A new aphrodisiac had been selling on the streets, fermented crab meat. The merchant used his connections within the cities authorities to get it banned, but it only increased it’s value as it started to be smuggled into the city.

boardgame.name: Spawning Pool
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A tight tunnel of fel encased stone leads you into the depths of the demonic mountain. Rocky chambers have formed and continue deeper via small corridors and slippery steps. Loose rocky gravel covers the chambers floors and when you finally reach the bottom of the cavern system you find a large pool of green ooze, eggs of hideous creatures and large tendrils.

boardgame.name: 50 Sea Dogs 9
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Shiver me timbers! This list provides 50 detailed pirates and other scurvy ridden sea dogs to infest your ships and saucy portside taverns with. Included in each entry is the following: First name and surname, gender (most are males but there are a few lasses), a general descriptive element about the character, weapon(s) carried and used, coins on their person, and a special treasure/carried item.

Random roll the percentile dice to use just one or a few, or fill up that cursed old galleon with the whole wretched lot of these scoundrels!

This list is suitable for historical era and fantasy settings alike.

boardgame.name: 100 Professionals Set 10
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This list contains 100 different professionals that are perfect drop ins for a modern/crime role playing game. This list is also useful for survivors for a post apocalyptic or zombie outbreak setting as well as a cyberpunk/near future dystopia that has many existing modern day occupations and elements. Included in each entry is first and last name, gender, age, and occupational skill/role.

boardgame.name: 100 Alien Biome Locations 08
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Need to flesh out some quick locations for that planet the characters are on but you don’t have time to think up anything? Use this list instead! This product features 100 space age locations that can be dropped on to most worlds. Included is a full name (with geographic type) as well as some notable feature or something the characters would find in the particular location.

10-10 was designed for the 2019 exhibition これはトリテなのか (Is this a trick-taking game?), for games that pushed the boundary of what could be considered both a game and a trick-taking game.

The game uses a deck of 55 cards, each with a major rank and a minor rank. The major and minor ranks both follow the one 1, two 2s, three 3s... structure. However, the combinations are structured such that the 1 occurs on 2 cards (1-10 and 10-1), while the 10 occurs on 19 cards (10-10 through 10-1, and 1-10 through 10-10). The cards are suitless.

In the game, rather than the suit of the lead player's card, it is the combination of cards played by the first and second players that determines what must be followed. If the major ranks of the first 2 cards match, then subsequent players may only play a card with that major rank. If the minor ranks of the first 2 cards match, then subsequent players may only play a card with that minor rank.

However, if the first and second card share neither the same major or minor rank, then all subsequent cards can match no previously played cards' major or minor ranks.

Players earn 1 point per trick taken, and the game lasts a number of rounds equal to the players. The person with the most points at the end of the game wins.

boardgame.name: 不器用な２人 (They Two Are Clumsy)
boardgame.description:
不器用な２人 (They Two Are Clumsy) was designed for the 2019 exhibition これはトリテなのか (Is this a trick-taking game?), for games that pushed the boundary of what could be considered both a game and a trick-taking game.

It is a game for 2 people that uses a seven-suit deck, with one suit ranking 1-7, one 2-8, another 3-9, etc. The game also uses a board, some chips, and another set of cards ranked 1-7.

Each player is dealt one card from each suit and during play, must follow suit.

In the game, the players are competing for the same love interest, and thematically, winning a trick causes a player to move closer or further from that goal. Depending upon the suit that player won the trick with, they may be able to activate a special ability.

The loser of a trick either earns coins which can be used to increase the rank of card(s) in the future, or draws a new card from a suit still in their hand and then returns one of the two cards in that suit to the bottom o the deck.

Points are won when a player passes the other on the love track and based upon the distance from the other player at the end of the round.

The players complete two rounds and the person with the most points wins.

boardgame.name: 100 Medieval Treats and Sweets
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This list features 100 treats and sweets pulled directly from or inspired by medieval to early renaissance cook books. These detailed and delicious listings range from rose custards to date and fig rysschews to apple tarts with cloves and ginger. Also included is a handy glossery of terms which expalins the more unusual or archaic treats.

So, whether you're looking to fill a pastry shop or describe the offerings at a feats, you'll find it all here!

boardgame.name: 100 Fae Blooded Traits
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This list features 100 traits for fae blooded characters that may reveal a bit of their fairy ancestry. These traits, directly inspired by Celtic, Scandinavian, and Slavic folklore, provide a wide range of options for fae blooded characters. Some traits merely affect appearance, such as perhaps having moss like hair or the tail of a cow. Others will affect the way that they are treated by others, such as frequently inspiring songs and poems or cattle and horses frequently spooking when they're near. All of them though, will bring a touch of the otherworldly magic of the fae to your character in a way that’s sure to help make things interesting.

boardgame.name: Poppetti: 5e Player Race
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

“We’ll just finish with the hair…and there now, just the picture isn’t she?”

- Morga Dalwreth, Gnomish Poppetti crafter


Born from want, grief, and sometimes greed, Poppetti are a unique group created by binding the souls of the dead to dolls of wood and cloth by the use of mysterious rituals. Though these rituals are known to be imperfect many are still willing to take the risk for this strange form of second life.

This booklet contains all the stats required to create a Poppetti player character, as well as a guide to their creation and lore.

boardgame.name: Fantasy European Castle
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Wait here, my lady will be with you shortly.

The lord and lady, the ladies in waiting, the bustling court, the flurry of servants going to and fro, a castle an ever constant hum of activity. Unfortunately the residents of the castle beyond the ruling family are often overlooked. This supplement aims to fix that gap with 24 interesting NPCs.

Each of the following entries has the name, age, profession, main personality traits, appearance, a short biography, and a quote from the npc. It is my hope that this information will provide enough background for a set of lively, dynamic NPCs for you to throw in to any game at a moment’s notice.

boardgame.name: The Collector (5E)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Through the hustle and bustle of the busy tavern, you notice the front doors open. A tall man with brown hair, and a finely trimmed mustache and goatee enters the room. He wears a bright red shirt that is stitched together with silver thread. A jeweled sword hangs from his hip. He is flanked by 6 heavily armed men. Each of the 6 men wears a uniform, colored red and black with gold trim. An intimidatingly large Irish Wolfhound, with a gold collar, follows the tall man faithfully. The tall man heads towards the crowded bar.

As the man approaches the bar, the rowdy farmers that surround it fall silent and move out of his way. They seem more star struck by this man, than afraid. The tall man turns to the bartender and orders a drink.

As the bartender hurriedly fumbles to prepare the drink, the tall man turns around and examines the room. A slight smile sneaks onto his face.

He is a man of wealth, status, and privilege, known as the Collector. When he wants something, he gets it, by any means necessary. And you have something that he wants.

How will your players react when they find out that a rich and powerful man is after their most prized possession? And to what lengths will they go to get it back?

Designed for players from levels 3-6. Though feel free to adjust the module's difficulty for any level group that you wish to play with.

boardgame.name: The Collector (PF1)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Through the hustle and bustle of the busy tavern, you notice the front doors open. A tall man with brown hair, and a finely trimmed mustache and goatee enters the room. He wears a bright red shirt that is stitched together with silver thread. A jeweled sword hangs from his hip. He is flanked by 6 heavily armed men. Each of the 6 men wears a uniform, colored red and black with gold trim. An intimidatingly large Irish Wolfhound, with a gold collar, follows the tall man faithfully. The tall man heads towards the crowded bar.

As the man approaches the bar, the rowdy farmers that surround it fall silent and move out of his way. They seem more star struck by this man, than afraid. The tall man turns to the bartender and orders a drink.

As the bartender hurriedly fumbles to prepare the drink, the tall man turns around and examines the room. A slight smile sneaks onto his face.

He is a man of wealth, status, and privilege, known as the Collector. When he wants something, he gets it, by any means necessary. And you have something that he wants.

How will your players react when they find out that a rich and powerful man is after their most prized possession? And to what lengths will they go to get it back?

Designed for players from levels 3-6. Though feel free to adjust the module's difficulty for any level group that you wish to play with.

boardgame.name: The Collector: Roll20 Map Pack
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

THIS IS JUST A MAP PACK.

This is optional add-on content for:

The Collector (5E)
The Collector (PF1)


These maps are formatted for use in Roll20, or in other VTT's. The maps also come with duplicate copies for the DM with Area Numbers on it.

Includes:

1 Forest Camp Map
1 Tavern Map
2 Maps of the Collector's Manor (1st and 2nd Floor)

boardgame.name: Ex Novo
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Ex Novo is a playable city-building generator to construct fictional villages and towns. This role-playing game can be played alone or with up to 3 friends. Playtime ranges from 1 to 3 hours. Meet with your friends and collaboratively draw the map of your city as you explore the conditions that led to its founding and the events that shape its development. Ex Novo helps you generate settlements that you will be itching to play in!

Playing Ex Novo

You (and up to three friends) take on the role of the guardian spirit of a freshly founded settlement. Its founding just brought you into existence. And with it it brought you your purpose: to witness its growth, shepherd its development and remember its stories.

As you play you will make sense of the events happening as you draw and plan on a collaborative map of the settlement and its changing shape. In the end you will have created an interesting fictional place with a sense of history.

boardgame.name: Hold Your Own
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Hold your Own is a one-page no-prep role-playing game for 3-5 players.

It's a time and place not unlike the one in which you, the players, grew up: a dark mirror of the decade of your youth. You play as a group of friends at the cusp of adolescence. Life is hard. You're unpopular and unwanted. All you've got is each other.

But it gets worse: A strange menace threatens to devour everyone you know. And nobody believes you, not your teachers, not your parents. It looks like it's up to you to save your home.

boardgame.name: The Door of Shadows Puzzle With Bonus Puzzle: The Corridor of Lava Rocks
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Included are two Fantasy RPG Puzzles with a Dungeon Map to use in your game.

Door of Shadows: The adventurers have found an upright door in the middle of a dark dungeon room. They may walk around it, through it, or go over it and nothing happens. Further exploration will be needed as they need to find some type of contraption to activate the door of shadows!

Corridor of Lava Rocks: A magical corridor that will cause the traveler’s feet to incinerate from the intense heat of its embers. Those that travel the corridor of lava rocks should only do so after applying the proper foot protection!

boardgame.name: Candlelight
boardgame.description:
From the publisher's website:

Candlelight is a role playing game about the restless spirits of treasure hunters seeking to escape a haunted forest and find hope as they reckon with their dark past. It is a one-shot, rules-light game, focusing on collaborative and thematic storytelling and is designed to be flexible in how you bring it to the table:

[*] An epilogue for any fantasy game following character death - especially a TPK!
[*] A world-building prologue for any game needing a haunted forest or other cursed place.
[*] A stand-alone game exploring themes of dark fantasy and supernatural horror - with a glimmering of hope and redemption.

boardgame.name: Wally DM's Journal of Puzzle Encounters
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Hello there adventurers and welcome to Wally DM! Thank you for purchasing my Journal of Puzzle Encounters. Within this journal you will find 60 puzzles that you can use to add an element of mystery, intrigue and fun to your fantasy role-playing games.

Your players will have their characters swapping out gems of an owl statue to open doors, turning their hand to stone to unlock a portal, or tasting a cube to see if its bitter or sweet in order to solve a puzzle.

Also included is a table of 100 weird rooms that you can use to populate your dungeons and bring out the creativity of both yourself and your players.

As you peruse the puzzles within these pages please remember that each puzzle is simply an idea for you to use “as is” or as the foundation of building your own encounters and ideas.

In a style of puzzles supported by thousands of wonderful subscribers to the Wally DM YouTube channel, the Journal of Puzzle Encounters will provide your table with legendary stories and moments they will always remember!

boardgame.name: Oligarchy
boardgame.description:
From the website:

Oligarchy is a game of political horror, Rooted in Trophy. You play as rotten bastards: corrupt politicians, decadent aristocrats, and other greedy elites. You are each determined to maximize your own wealth and comfort while your actions tear society apart around you. Eventually, society will tolerate your abuses no more. But the iron confidence that is your privileged birthright makes you certain you will avoid that doom. You'll do anything to make sure you get yours (and get away with it).

boardgame.name: What Do You Meme?: The Office Expansion Pack
boardgame.description:
Alert your coworkers, clear off the lunch table and get ready to play What Do You Meme, Dunder-Mifflin-style. Michael, Dwight, Jim and Pam and more faves are all here in our The Office-themed expansion pack!

Contains: 50 brand new caption cards and 30 photo cards to be added to the core game.

listing.notes: Stored on my shelf B1

boardgame.name: TiRoBEx: Tiny Robots, Big Explosions
boardgame.description:
The name says it all.
Take control of the smallest robots, and run amok on the battlefield with explosions so huge that they cause the very ground to shake, obscure your vision and create a fireball so big that it lasts well into the following turns of the game. Allocate your power to ensure your tiny robot has the best chance of survival; will you increase your attack, attempt to dodge incoming fire, run like the wind?

Whatever you choose, don't forget about the resources scattered around the board, these could make or break your game...
TiRoBEx is set in the far future, a time when mankind has begun to explore the far reaches of space. With technological advances, and the discovery of a super fuel called Tyridium, remotely controlled robots no bigger than a child (and in most cases smaller) are able to perform the tasks of armies of men.

This game simulates the militaristic side of the robots use – in attempts to destroy opponents and secure resource rich environments of newly discovered worlds orbiting distant star systems.

With an innovative system of 3-D Blast templates that gradually reduce in size, TiRoBEx takes wargaming to a whole new level - a really, really low down level. The complete rules and printable versions of the templates and tokens are contained within a single full-colour rulebook.

Each 'Tiny Robot System' (TRS) has a unique reference card with values for various attributes that you can alter during the game. Tyridium (like an individual energy store) can be allocated to many different systems; Movement, Range of Attack, Number of Attacks, Accuracy, Shield Generation, Evasion capabilities, or to power-up the devastating Area Impact (AI) Rounds. All this in an attempt to destroy your opponent(s) and secure unrefined Tyridium around the battlefield.

The main TiRoBEx rulebook contains full rules for eight different TRS, from four of the largest factions in the future of humankind as they explore the vast reaches of the cosmos, in a bid to claim the Tyridium scattered throughout the stars for themselves.

They may be small, but they can have a BIG impact!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Mythic Encounters: The Bullywug Ascendant
boardgame.description:
"Bullywug are a swamp-dwelling creature of varying repute. Some humanoid civilizations call them primitive, others call them backwards, but neither is close to the truth. Bullywug are a voracious race, that exists with an insatiable hunger. They strip-feed off the land around them and devastate the wetland marshes in which they thrive, forcing them to move like locusts.

However, the bullywug civilization of Chelimber is built on revering the largest, most powerful creature they know of. This is thought to scholars as to why they gorge themselves, to become like that which they deify.

Never the less, the frog-like creatures are not to be taken lightly, and are capable of great things when called to task. Many have even been known to change their predisposition and seek larger things in life: adventure, riches, fame, knowledge, exploration.

The Bullywug Ascendant is not one of these bullywug, though. First prophecized by a cleric of Ramenos (the Sleeping God) who saw in imbibement-induced visions the figure of a godking bullywug who had tamed a mighty Froghemeth (possibly the avatar of Ramenos reborn), the ascendant was storied about in Chelimber for years to come.

In 1492 DR, that day did come. The bullywug swarm leader, Fushim, who had grown so bloated he could not move with the hoard after a section of the marshland had been stripped clean, called to the aid of Ramenos to draw him into a deep sleep so that he might pass the time while digesting his meal. Instead of this, beyond the horizon, the slick springing followed by the thunderous boom drew Fushim’s attention from his listful prayers. Another slick spring, this time louder and more forceful, was followed by a total eclipse of the sun. The sudden and unexpected darkness caused Fulshim great disorientation, but it did not last long. For the sun came back as the thunderous boom erupted again from within meters of his gluttonous form. His eyes adjusted for just the brief moment, to see another large bullywug figure sitting atop the largest froghemoth he had ever seen. Then, the froghemoth enveloped the swarm leader in one swift gulp, and it and its rider moved onward.

Or at least, that is how the story goes. None questioned the Ascendant when he arrived at the swarm, declaring himself their new leader. For he was the largest, and the Ascendant, and that made him a god among them."

(Author Summary)

boardgame.name: UnderGods
boardgame.description:
UnderGods is a unique Dual Strategic, resource Oriented Deck-Building, board game with a competitive/cooperative mode.

2-5+ Multiplayer with Single player (*)
Quick (sideB) or Story (sideA) Mode
Playing time: (45 -120) min
Ages: 13+

Turn based game, with different starting points on the board.

Choose from 96 Characters of 4 mythologies: Celtic, Egyptian, Greek and Norse. Available to hire at the Temple. You will be fighting other player Characters from being forgotten. If you save enough Gods you win the game.

Standard Quest cards represent goals, are available at the Shrine. Players who complete a certain number of Quests can also win the game.

Item cards represent weapons, shields to equip your Characters and are available to buy at the Barracks.

When equipping some Characters with their own personal Items, that provides extra actions.

Skills & Treasure cards represent abilities and loot you can choose from. There are 4 types of Skills: Fighter, Mage, Ranger and Thief. All with different actions to use in your turn.

Treasures are the rewards every player gets from fighting, only available after entering the Underworld.

The Goal of the game is to win by saving enough Gods or completing a number of Quests while fighting other players.

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Gate: Game Mat
boardgame.description:
Keep your plays of Gate thematic and organized!

If you are looking for a great way to enhance your experience while playing GATE, then the 10x16" roll-up neoprene game mat is just what you are looking for.

The mat will really set the mood with its vibrant and spooky design and bold lines.

The mat will also keep all your cards in order, for a cleaner and more organized play.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Zirkus Bumsti
boardgame.description: The players start at space 1 and have to go to space 50. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

boardgame.name: Weihnachtstellereisbahn
boardgame.description:
The players have to skate from start to finish. Movement is determined by a die. If a player lands on a white space he has to move backwards on his next turn. On a red space the player topples and misses a turn. If he land on a ginger bread he may roll and move again. The first player to reach the finish wins the game.

The game board may be folded into a Christmas plate.

boardgame.description:
Meadow is an engaging set collection game with over two hundred unique cards containing hand-painted watercolor illustrations. In the game, players take the role of explorers competing for the title of the most skilled nature observer. To win, they collect cards with the most valuable species, landscapes, and discoveries. Their journey is led by passion, a curiosity of the world, an inquiring mind, and a desire to discover the mysteries of nature. The competition continues at the bonfire where the players race to fulfill the goals of their adventures.

In this medium-weight board game for 1-4 players, you take turns placing path tokens on one of the two boards. Placing a token on the main board allows the player to get cards, but playing them requires meeting certain requirements. Playing a token on the bonfire board activates special actions (which helps to implement a chosen strategy) and gives the opportunity to achieve goals that provide additional points. Throughout the game, players collect cards in their meadow and surroundings area. At the end, the player with the most points on cards and on the bonfire board wins.

Meadow also includes envelopes with additional cards to open at specific moments...

boardgame.name: Albastini Card Game
boardgame.description:
Albastini is a competitive trick-taking multiplayer card game which is originally from Tanzania, East Africa.

It can be played with 2 to 8 players individually or in teams of 2, 3, or 4 players (i.e. 2v2, 3v3, 2v2v2, 4v4, or 2v2v2v2).

There are 72 cards per deck (8 suits with 9 cards per suit) A=11pts; 7=10pts; K=4pts; J=3pts; Q=2pts; 3-6=0pts.

It typically takes 15+ mins to play but players can opt to play with only 4 of the suits for faster game play (this is typically only encouraged if 2 - 4 players are playing).

It is played clockwise with one card per hand. Players start off with five cards and pick a card from the deck every time a hand is played starting with the winner of the last hand. The game ends after all cards within the deck have been played.

The objective of the game is to get the highest number of points.

A trump suit is randomly selected at the beginning of each game which can be used to dominate all other cards regardless of their point value.

The first card played within each round determines the suit that is in play for that round. It can only be beaten if a higher value card within the same suit is played or any trump card. Players do not have to follow suit during each round.

The player (or team) with the highest number of points at the end of the game is declared the winner.

boardgame.name: Oathsworn: Into the Deepwood – The Armory
boardgame.description:
The Armory is a cosmetic weapon pack for Oathsworn: Into the Deepwood.

boardgame.name: Imaginarium: Chimera
boardgame.description:
Dreams are central to the Imaginarium: Chimera expansion. To every machine is added a dream, its "soul". Once a turn, instead of doing one of the two actions you chose, you can spend some time dreaming — and if your dreams are persistent, you can win extra resources or victory points (VPs) — or even end the game earlier than normal.

In addition to new projects and assistants, this expansion includes components to allow for play with up to six players, but only in the new "team play" mode in which teammates share resources, VPs, and broken machines. Good communication allows for combined actions...

boardgame.name: Codex Naturalis
ماتیکان
自然法則
코덱스
boardgame.description:
In CODEX Naturalis, you must continue the work of the illuminating monk Tybor Kwelein, assembling the pages of a manuscript that lists the living species in primary forests. Can you put the pages together in the best order possible? And are you prepared to sacrifice a species to develop your manuscript?

In the game, each player starts with a single card on the table, a card that shows some combination of the four possible resources in the middle of the card, in the corners of the card, or both. Players also have two resource cards and one gold card in hand, while two of each type of card are visible on the table.

On a turn, you place a card from your hand overlapping the corners of one or more cards you already have in play. Your starting card has four overlappable corners, while resource and gold cards have only three.


Resource cards have no cost to be played, and they often depict resource symbols in their corners.
Gold cards deliver points when played, but they often have a resource requirement, e.g., three fungi or two plant/one animal/one insect, and you must have those resources visible in your manuscript at the time you play the gold card. You score points from this card immediately, with some cards having a fixed value and others a variable one depending on how many of a certain symbol are showing or how many corners you covered this turn.


If you wish, you can play a card from your hand face down; such a card has four corners and one resource, but provides no points. After you play, draw a face-up card or the top card of either deck to refill your hand.

When a player reaches 20 points, you complete the round, and each player takes one additional turn. Players then score points based on how well they matched two public objective cards and one secret objective card, after which the player with the most points wins.

boardgame.name: Vespula: Das turbulente Wespenspiel!
boardgame.description:
Recognize and win the wasp species with speed and skill, just like in flight.

Are you the fastest wasp of them all? Win your races with speed. But watch out, otherwise you will fly wrong.

Playfully discover the fascinating variety of wasps. It's about fun, speed, a close look and learning wasp species.

Contents: 88 playing cards, 9 "Who are you?" Cards, and game instructions with information on the individual types.

Goal of the game:
All players are workers in a wasp colony. But who is the most hardworking and gets rid of their cards first?
You need to pay attention to all the details and distinguish all the kinds of wasp species as fast as possible.

Put a makeshift "cocoon" into the middle of the game (e.g. a piece of wood) and distribute all cards as drawpiles to the players.

One after the other, each player uncovers the top card of their draw pile and puts it onto their personal discard pile.

If two cards with the same motive are visible at the same time, the two players who own these two cards, need to touch the "cocoon" as quickly as possible.

The player who touches the cocoon first, gives all their uncovered cards to the slower player. This player needs to put all own uncovered cards, as well as the other player's cards back onto their draw pile.

If both players touch the cocoon at the same time, the player who can identify the wasp species first, wins.

Once a player's draw pile is empty, the player skips the uncovering of cards. But they still need to get rid off all open cards on the discard pile.

The game ends when one player got rid of all cards.

boardgame.name: Cat and Mouse

Cat sees mouse. Cat sits down and designs a mousetrap? Wait...what? Well, in our new Cat And Mouse adventure, play as one of our fuzzy little friends and try and outsmart Lucifer the Cat in a series of misadventures in the spirit of slapstick cartoon mayhem!

Cat and Mouse features the epic battle between an animated cat named Lucifer and the mice (player characters) that infest his master’s home.

boardgame.name: More Custom Ancestries & Cultures
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

'Sixty-Four Ancestries & Cultures To Replace Race in 5e!

Based on Ancestry & Culture: An Alternative to Race in 5e
64 new ancestries & cultures
Cultures based on the 11 geographic terrains and 8 planes of existence
Fun new options like Owlbear Kin and Terrasquer, pictured below

boardgame.name: Sector Treks
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Follow the not-so-famous Kywokki explorer Grondabogga through 5 different adventures that range from one end of Galaxy Prime to the other!

The Institute for Genetic and Evolutionary Health has made a discovery that may revive the Nilite species!
A Gluggan scientist thought he had found the cure for the plight of the Mutor but instead ended up turning his team into zombies!
Researchers come across volatile DNA evidence suggesting that the Zhani may not be the apex predators the galaxy thinks they are!
The Runarians and the Neuroth conspire to form a cult in order to create invincible warriors out of the Dirritt!
A world’s entire economy is threatened by sharks, saboteurs and an active volcano!


Re-live these exciting scenarios in Grondabogga’s compilation that will challenge any party of Galaxy Prime adventurers!
boardgame.rpg: Galaxy Prime: A Scifi Roleplaying Epic

boardgame.name: A Dozen Treacherous Encounters
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The number of possible encounters that you may access – either to expand into a larger scene or to use as inspiration for an encounter of your own design – grows by twelve with this latest release in the A Dozen . . . series of PDFs. This time around, I’ve provided twelve encounters you can draw from that each include combat and non-combat options.

As always, it is my hope that the twelve encounters described on the following pages spark your own creativity and lead to enjoyable game sessions that are unlike what any other GM could imagine. As a storyteller, it is your job during the session to entertain the players, and only you know best how to adapt published game concepts to fit the tastes of your group.

boardgame.name: A Dozen Warriors for Hire
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

As the player characters grow in experience and power, there may come a point in the campaign when they decided that it is time to hire others to assist them in tasks within the game world. While there are almost no limits to the professions of those the PCs may hire, it should not come as a surprise when the party wishes to hire mercenaries – swords for hire – to aid them in a particularly challenging dungeon adventure.

It is for those moments that I have created the twelve characters described within the pages of this PDF. As with other releases in the A Dozen . . . series, all of the content is systemless, meaning that none of the characters include game statistics. Fortunately, most games include stats for a number of classes at different levels of power, which means that all you need to add to those stats are names and some backstory to make instant hirelings. And that, as you have already guessed, is where A Dozen Warriors for Hire enters the picture.

As NPCs within the campaign, these warriors may also serve as allies or enemies of the party . . . the exact relationship might depend on how each was treated when serving as a hireling.

boardgame.name: The Everrain: Metal Coins
boardgame.description:
Metal coins for The Everrain in values 5, 10 & 20.

Replaces the cardboard coins that come in the basic edition of The Everrain.

Contains 50 metal coins in bronze (20), silver (20) & gold (10).

boardgame.name: The Everrain: Acrylic Tokens
boardgame.description:
Acrylic Tokens for The Everrain.

Replaces the cardboard Order tokens that come in the basic edition of The Everrain. The Order tokens are used to issue orders to your crew and come in Crew, Movement and Attack varieties.

Contains 50 acrylic tokens with approximately 3mm in thickness.

boardgame.name: Star Classes: Nanomancer
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Harness the Power of Nanotechnology!
Have you longed to reduce your foes to atomic dust? Aspire to become a walking nano-factory capable of fabricating anything you can imagine at a moment's notice? Then leave the frailty of mere biology behind and embrace the future with the Mechanist, a new class for Starfinder that harnesses the promise of nanites to carve out its own niche in your game! A hybrid class combining some of the drone elements of the Mechanic with the spell casting of the Technomancer, and adding its own unique nanite powered techniques, the Mechanist is sure to infuse your game with its own brand of nano-enhancing magi-tech.

boardgame.name: The Sun Below: That's How the Light Gets In
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

When someone steals your sun and takes it to another dimension, you have to give chase.

A Numenera adventure for all tiers.

The Sun Below has been stolen. Most of thieves are gone, but the PCs find one of the thieves' transdimensional ships, the Gravitas Mislaid, has tarried. It's possible for the PCs to get aboard and follow the other thieves to where the Sun Below was taken.

Once aboard, the explorers find the ship contains three different planes of existence, a new spin on the term three dimensional. There they can deal with transdimensional pirates, horrific creatures, a squid headed woman with her own agenda, and maybe even meet an old friend.

The Gravitas Mislaid docks at the City of Lost Worlds. This transdimensional nexus is run by the Terrible Beauties, the very god-like beings who stole the Sun Below. This city is the perfect sandbox for your players to explore as they figure out how to get to the vault that contains their sun. Enemies, allies, and many shades of gray populate this multi-planar city. Your PCs may visit a virtual hell to speak with a dead criminal, dine in luxury under a toxic atmosphere to gather information, and gain unlikely allies in their quest.

The Terrible Beauties have a bit of a sun-vault, in a pocket (a very big pocket) dimension known as the Saturated Sanctum. Getting in is just the beginning. For then the PCs must hijack a giant automaton which can rescue their sun.

This adventure is designed for all kinds of players. If your players want to fight things, they can. If they want to talk their way out of problems, they can. If they want to sneak past problems, they can.

No matter what path they take, there will be plenty of content left over for your own adventures. The City of Lost Worlds is a great place to visit whenever your players go transdimensional.

Players can choose a new race, the four-armed vikrons from a high-energy dimension and gain abilities from a new flavor, the dimension walker. Not to mention a huge bestiary, a big cast of fleshed out NPCs, new equipment, cyphers, and artifacts.

boardgame.name: Monopoly: Folkestone
boardgame.description:
From the publisher:

"Tour Folkestone for the hottest properties: sites, travel spaces and local services are all up for grabs. Invest in houses and hotels, then watch the rent come pouring in! Make deals with other players and look out for bargains at auction - there are many ways to get what you want. Stay sharp, because there's only room at the top for one. For everyone else, there's bankruptcy. Trade your way to success - you can own it all! MONOPOLY has made its way to the diverse city of Folkestone.

Key Features

The world’s favourite family board game brings you another exciting edition of MONOPOLY – Folkestone!
Choose your favourite token, tour your favourite sites and accumulate fortunes, but watch out for taxes, jail and bankruptcy
Advance to Folkestone's historical sites – will you owe rent or reap the rewards?
Invest in houses and hotels and trade your way to success
The Fast-Dealing Property Trading Game is fun for the whole family"

boardgame.name: The Everrain: Dice
boardgame.description:
Dice for The Everrain.

There are 4 Sets for each of the Player Ships for The Everrain available.


purple - "The Ivory Sword"
red - "The Pariah"
turquoise - "The Bitter End"
yellow - "The Aberconway"


Contains 10 dice each set with 5 Marble and 5 with Gem effect.

boardgame.name: Kobayashi Maru
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Test Your Mettle Against the Classic No-Win Scenario!

Attention, cadets! Now is your chance to step up and attempt the most important test of your Academy career. When a disabled freighter near the Klingon Neutral Zone sends out a distress signal, you and your crew must respond. How will you fare during the Kobayashi Maru scenario?

This standalone 15-page PDF adventure by Jo Kreil is for the Star Trek Adventures Roleplaying Game and is set during The Original Series era. This adventure also contains advice for adaptation for use in campaigns based in other Star Trek eras.

boardgame.name: Guardians of Sol-Tau
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Sol-Tau is a solar system in a faraway galaxy, inhabited by technologically-advanced races who, for several centuries, lived in peace.

That is until the Iods came.

30 years ago the Iods conquered and subdued Sol-Tau and, after having established a military dictatorship and exploited all possible resources, they are ready to rip off all the remaining energy within the solar system with a mysterious mega-machine called “the Hrax” - a device that will be thrown at the system’s twin suns, snuffing it out, to fuel their gargantuan Arcaship and allow them to set sail towards another solar system to conquer and exploit.

The time for the final solution is, unfortunately, at hand. But a secret society, guided by an obscure prophecy, is at work to save Sol-Tau. All they need is a crew of unwitting heroes to do the most important part of the job!

Guardians of Sol-Tau is a sci-fi adventure for 3-6 Seasoned characters, designed to be played in one or two sessions packed full of action!

It only requires the Savage Worlds Adventure Edition book and, optionally, the Aces High supplement to play highly cinematographic space dogfights. Don’t have Aces High? Check THIS BUNDLE we’ve made for you!

Guardians of Sol-Tau is a light-hearted space romp adventure, where unwitting heroes become involved in a desperate mission to save their solar system from destruction and possibly put an end the Iods’ tyranny forever.

The story unfolds through eight scenes with several different rules subsystems in action:

Networking
Social Conflict
Chase
Dramatic Task
Quick Encounter
Interlude
and of course Combat!


making it the perfect adventure for new players and GMs to explore or learn all the possibilities of the Savage Worlds Adventure Edition rules!

boardgame.name: The Worldship of the Ulvantar
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Scavange & Get Paid!

The Ulvantar were a highly intelligent race of humanoid beings, with long heads and head-tails, that travelled the stars in their huge Worldships, great gestalt vessels dozens of kilometres in length that housed millions, entire generations of their kind. These ships carried them between planets for trade and exploration and, most importantly, they carried them away from their home star system which had been ravaged by a deadly genetic plague, which is what turned them into stellar nomads in the first place. Their technical skills were unmatched and they were
often sought out for their genius and craft.

Sadly, the plague caught up with them and in a short amount of time their species were wiped from the face of the galaxy. Their Worldships, however, continued to fly and, in the centuries since their passing, the vessels of the Ulvantar have been found and stripped. All have been empty husks, destroyed by lack of care and unattended systems.

However, an Ulvantar Worldship has appeared in the Holska Sector, and the rumour is that it is in almost perfect condition... so perfect that every explorer, chancer, space ranger, rocket jockey, fortune hunter and any and all the rascals of the universe are heading for it’s last reported position in the hope that the vessel with gift them with hoards of Xenotech.

boardgame.name: Evangelyne “Eva” Kirby & Randall “Ares” Seaton
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The tallest structures in Arcadia City, the Twilight Towers, serve as home base for the technology conglomerate Twilight, Inc. These three skyscrapers, connected via skywalks, feature some of the most modern and recognizable architecture in the world. Thousands of researchers, technicians, and administrators work here every day to improve the world through scientific advances and new technology.

The towers boast an artificial intelligence (AI) system, known as Mercury Six, designed to manage every facet of the three buildings, ranging from energy management to lighting to security. Through its first two years of operation, Mercury Six proved so reliable and efficient the corporation planned to offer the system to governments and other companies. Unfortunately, these plans evaporated following a cyber-attack that hijacked the AI.

The attack began late in the evening when the majority of the towers’ occupants had left for the day. Lights flickered, temperatures fluctuated, and grunge metal music roared over the intercom system. The attacker’s electronically distorted image appeared on every viewscreen, at which point he announced his cringeworthy name: Techno Wizard. He listed his demands, including $500 million, a lifetime’s supply of pizza hot pocket sandwiches, and his own island in the Caribbean. He threatened to harm the people in the buildings and release the company’s trade secrets if they failed to meet his demands.

This PDF contains everything you need to know about the Twilight Inc. members, Evangelyne “Eva” Kirby & Randall “Ares” Seaton in the Amazing Universe Campaign or any other superhero campaign.
boardgame.rpgseries: Official Handbook of the Amazing Universe

boardgame.name: Last Vestige of Hope
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Last Vestige of Hope is an adventure for 4 to 6 low-level characters that are just starting their initial ex-plorations of the ravaged wastelands within a devastated Earth. It is a story of desperation, daring, and ultimately, at its conclusion, great achievement. It pits the characters against despicable humans and hungry, non-human foes for the first time. Although this adventure could be dropped into any existing campaign, it is ideal for newly created characters who are leaving (willingly or forcefully) the safety of their settlement for the very first time.

This adventure was designed for use with first edition Gamma World but can be adapted to any post-apocalyptic roleplaying game.

boardgame.name: In Burgha's Sanctum
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A 5th Edition Mini-Dungeon for four characters of level 4

The adventurers arrive at the Sanctum of Lady Burgha, patron saint of retired adventurers, to make use of its celebrated resurrection pool. However, a week ago, an aridni named Finch Brushwood took over the sanctum with a troop of extraplanar fey creatures, slaying the usual caretakers. Most of the fey regard the “invasion” as a humorous lark, but Finch slowly leeches the power of the resurrection pool into a gem to present to the Fey Queen.

boardgame.name: Space Dogs
boardgame.description:
Space Dogs need homes on earth. All players are owners of dog agencies. Your goal is to find homes for Space Dogs by fulfilling contract requirements.

Each turn a player draws cards from the Space pile and can do 3 actions like playing a card (dog,training or event), draw and/or transferring cards while trying to fulfill a Contract card. The game end triggers when a player gets 10 Points (total from the Contract cards) and at the end of that round the player with the most points wins the game!

boardgame.name: The Seed
boardgame.description:
This book is part of a collection called Manifestus Omnivorous:

1. All books are adventures.
2. The adventures must be system-agnostic.
3. The adventures must take place on Earth.
4. The adventures can only have one location.
5. The adventures can only have one monster.
6. The adventures must include saprophagy or osteophagy.
7. The adventures must include a voracious eater.
8. The adventures must have less than 6,666 words.
9. The adventures can only be in two colours.
The lost rule:
10. The adventures cannot have good taste.

Kelvin Green makes one of the most elegant and clever interpretations of the Manifestus Omnivorous to date. Yes, the adventure is set on EARTH – very obviously so. And, yes, the LOCATION is very much ordinary – a remote village called Midwich. But, the one MONSTER is unlike anything you’ve seen: a giant alien terraforming bio-machine that is simply standing in the middle of town, EATING AWAY at the world and spitting out a new environment. Inspired by the likes of the fungal realm in Star Trek and the miasma in Miyazaki’s Nausicaa, the Seed is a pulpy tongue-in-cheek module ready to be plugged in into any existing campaign.

Who is Kelvin?

Kelvin Green is an English illustrator and writer. He is the author of various OSR modules like Forgive Us and Midvinter (LotFP) and, as an illustrator, known for his works in the B/X Companion (Running Beagle Games), The Weird that Befell Drigbolton (Necrotic Gnome) and Barbarians of the Ruined Earth (DIY Productions), amongst others.

What do you get?

The Seed is a system-agnostic module for use with any traditional roleplaying game. Comes with 28 pages in softcover slightly-bigger than A5 size. Fluorescent pink is everywhere.

boardgame.name: Cabin Risotto Fever
boardgame.description:
This book is part of a collection called Manifestus Omnivorous:

1. All books are adventures.
2. The adventures must be system-agnostic.
3. The adventures must take place on Earth.
4. The adventures can only have one location.
5. The adventures can only have one monster.
6. The adventures must include saprophagy or osteophagy.
7. The adventures must include a voracious eater.
8. The adventures must have less than 6,666 words.
9. The adventures can only be in two colours.
The lost rule:
10. The adventures cannot have good taste.

Spaghetti Quester’s interpretation of the Manifestus Omnivorous is a marvellous satire of academia and academic life wrapped around a B movies casing with a dash of Spaghetti Westerns and investigative horror. The LOCATION is a cabin in the woods set in Canada in the late 40s. The MONSTER is a Wendigo born out of HUNGER and despair. And, of course, OSTEOPHAGY is included in the form of a risotto made out of the bones of a young PhD student. Yummy. Included are psychedelic mushrooms, old Winchester rifles, professors with illusions of grandeur, and a night of horror that is not to forget. Cabin Risotto Fever is, in short, Call of Cthulhu meets Quentin Tarantino.

Who is Spaghetti Quester?

Spaghetti Quester is an Italian illustrator, known for his collaborations with Exalted Funeral and Old School Essentials, amongst many others. This is his first work as an author in the RPG industry.

What do you get?

Cabin Risotto Fever is a system-agnostic module for use with investigative and horror roleplaying games. Comes with 24 pages in softcover slightly-bigger than A5 size. Black and yellow are predominant.

boardgame.name: Partout
boardgame.description:
The trick-taking game Partout uses a 42-card deck that consists of 36 traditional number cards (1-9 in four suits) along with six special cards: King, Queen, Harlequin, Dungeon, Mathematican, Alchemist.

Players compete in two-player teams over six or eight rounds, and whoever ends up with highest score wins. In each round, players are dealt a hand of seven cards (ten cards for a three-player game), then the first and second player of the round announce the trump number and trump color. Players must state how many tricks they expect to win, then teammates add their claims together ; teams have to reach their summed number of tricks to score important bonus points, the value of which depends on the initial claim.

The playing and winning of tricks uses mostly standard trick-taking rules, with the exception that you don't have to follow the lead suit. Instead, the highest card wins the trick, which leads to often unpredictable victories because the six special cards have different skills.

To win the game, teams have to estimate the risk of stating the expected tricks, use the special cards cleverly, and harmonize as an unit without either of them knowing what the other person holds.

-description from designer

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

listing.notes: -new, but not in plastic packed -shipping cost not in price included

boardgame.name: Iwari: Deluxe Edition
boardgame.description:
Evermore have they walked the world of Iwari. Evermore have they embodied its spirit and shaped its lands. They are stewards of the earth. Five Titans that make the cosmos breath. On Iwari, there are no teeming masses, no continent-wide civilizations. Humanity is in its infancy, living in scattered tribes in forest, tundra, and desert.

Now we have left our ancestral homelands to explore the vast uncharted regions, encountering other fellow tribes and exchanging knowledge, culture and wisdom. In our journey, we all live in harmony with the Titans, and though distant to us, they decide our fate. And yet only we don't know if they created us, or we created them.

Iwari is an abstract-like Eurogame in which players represent different tribes looking for their identity by traveling around far lands and expanding their settlements into five different regions on the board. In the game, players use cards for two different actions:

1) Place tents and expand their settlements into five different regions on the board in a majority game that scores on each territory.
2) Construct nature totems to bond with the Titans by placing them on regions and score points based on the totem majorities in adjacent territories.

During the game, players can complete missions that grant small perks and score points by having the majority of tents in each territory after the end of the first card cycle. At game end, the majority of tents will be scored again, along with the majorities of nature totems in two adjacent regions and settlements that players have created (i.e., four or more tents in an uninterrupted sequence along one of the roads on the board).

Iwari reimagines the award-winning game Web of Power by Michael Schacht by adding new layers of strategy, tribe player boards, different maps with their own set of rules, modules that can be added to the game, and unique co-operative and solo modes.


Additional content in Deluxe Edition:

1 Double-sided game board: "The Forgotten Islands" and "The Void"
2 New maps: "The Uncharted Paths" and "The Long Road"
8 Plastic void totems
21 Silkscreen printing wooden void ruins
12 Void cards
Solo mode rules (separate rulebook)
10 Double-sided solo mode tikens
4 Mountains
Co-op Rules
16 Expedition cards
1 Feat: Courage
The Eagle pawn to use for the Feats: "Complacency" and "Worship"
2 Icebergs

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

listing.notes: Played once. Shipping is 16 or pickup around Indy or mid Michigan.

boardgame.name: Dead Reckoning: Metal Coins
boardgame.description:
Metal Coins for Dead Reckoning.

Replaces the cardboard coins that come in the basic edition of Dead Reckoning.

Contains 80 metal coins in values:


Forty 1 point coins
Twenty 3 point coins
Twelve 10 point coins
Eight 30 point coins

boardgame.name: Bones of the Companion
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Bones of the Companions invites only the bravest to save a city from damnation. The adventure is designed for mid to high-level player characters of levels 7 to 10. All character classes are useful though a paladin and cleric in the party would be advantageous. The adventure begins in a city, town, village or fortification and can be placed in any campaign setting. Bones of the Companions takes the characters from the basement of a recently deceased cleric to a place where “all Hell has broken loose.” The adventurers find themselves engaged in a struggle with powerful creatures in a monolithic maze for the dead.

Although Bones of the Companions can be played with just this module, it was inspired by several of Reaper’s miniatures and a map penned by Dyson Logos. Access to Reaper’s miniatures for the encounters brings life to the table for all players of the game. A list is provided but they are not necessary to play. It would be helpful for running the game to have a printer, pair of scissors and some graph stock to ‘construct’ the dungeon.

The party explores a crypt in a pocket universe which some demons have invaded. The crypt is constructed inside a cube in a pocket dimension. The crypt has a portal to the Abyss and demons have come through the portal after the death of a cleric who guarded the crypt. The characters are asked to investigate the source of a demon who recently rampaged through a city.

Bones of the Companions is an adventure designed for high-level play. It is suggested that the party have, minimally, 4 members with an average of 8th level. A mix of classes is necessary to successfully complete the adventure. It is nearly critical that cleric is a member of the adventuring party. It is especially useful if a paladin joins the fray.

boardgame.name: A Visitor's Guide to the Rainy City
boardgame.description:
"It’s the end of the world. It always rains. Rain beats against the walls. It seeps through the shutters. It pours off the mossy backs of the gargoyles. It turns streets into streams and rivers.

Teetering, damp towers lean against rotting townhouses thrown together in the ruins of a once gleaming city. Servants dash through storms on petty errands. Fireplaces sputter weakly, and spellbooks filled with moldy spells rot in spite of the protections lavished on them for their precious contents."

A VISITOR'S GUIDE TO THE RAINY CITY is a system-agnostic RPG zine offering a complete setting playset and toolkit for GMs and players alike to mine for your own games and campaign settings or drop into a campaign as is. Spice up your roleplaying with the weirdness, whimsy, and wickedness of the Rainy City - a doomed fantasy metropolis at the end of the world - where the wizards jealously guard their rotting magical tomes, the gargoyles are always watching, the thieves are on the prowl, and the rains never stop.

As a GM Playset & Toolkit
The VISITOR'S GUIDE is designed for busy GMs to mine for your own games and campaigns. Need a flavorful but dour neighborhood to drop into a city you're prepping? Then use the paranoid and cult-infested Levee Town. Need a strange NPC wizard for players to sell their ill-gotten loot to? Oculam the Oracular is your wizard; he already saw you coming! Need a weird urban location to toss in front of your players? Then look no further because Vengus Ult's Mushroom Library has just sprouted up in Old Town. Need a colorful folktale to flesh out your local village? Then Ware the Winder Man, who comes every Mid-Winder Night to enter your home and steal your breath.

Break the VISITOR'S GUIDE down, mine it for gems, and use them as your own.

As a Whole Setting
GMs can also use the VISITOR’S GUIDE as a complete, interconnected setting. The Rainy City can be dropped into the oceans of nearly any fantasy world, be found on the edges of the Elemental Plane of Water, or used as we use it -- as the last city left, where everyone and everything eventually washes up as world after world is destroyed by flood. Maybe it’s a place your regular characters pass through on their adventures. Maybe it’s a sort of Bermuda Triangle where they get stuck, for a while. Maybe it’s a pocket universe, maybe a dream, or even some sort of hell. If you can think of a use for a magic rich, rain-soaked city with an Age of Sail flavor that could house any sort of fantasy, you can drop the Rainy City into your campaign.

Take it, pair it with your favorite game, and make it your own.

(from the publisher)

boardgame.name: Igniting the Fire
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The world has never been as dark as it was in its earliest days.

The Forest. The Mountain. The Sea. The Winter. The Night. The Dead. The Living. The Others. Everything was a threat. Everything was an enemy. Everything was a danger. And then, the Wise came, turning the people to the People. However, the Wise are so few, and they are blinded by their power- and the darkness is so, so deep. The People must fight. The People must protect. Be them farmers and traders, potters and hunters and priests, each has their own role to fulfil, and to keep the People alive for one more night.

The world may be at its darkest- but the fire has never shined as bright as then.

Igniting the Fire is a Sundered World expansion, meant to give the tools to run and play a Hunter Chronicle during the Neolithic. This books includes:

The many threats and enemies against the People must fight in order to survive, be them the hungry dead, the disastrous Wild Hunt or the murderous Others.
Special roles for the People who uphold the Vigil, be them the emissaries of the Healers from the Forest, the outcast Grave-Stricken who speak for the dead or the barbarian communities who were Banished from the People.
Two conspiracies which may have existed among the People- the Hunter Wolf Cult and the Guardians of the Flame.
A new template to be used for both protagonists and antagonists, either for modern or Neolithic times- the Rmoahals
New Endowments, the future which waits for those first carriers of the Vigil, and more

boardgame.name: Strange Changes: Cernunni and Ursuma
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

There is no perfection in this world, and even the most consistent of cycles break. Predator and prey, hunter and hunted. Light and darkness wage an eternal war, raging from equinox to solstice and back. This is a world of cycles- and wherever they break, when the delicate balance is being distubed, the world changes, growing stranger and stranger.

This book contains:

The Cernunni- elusive weredeer who share an ancient bond to the Uratha since the times of Pangaea, always in danger of getting corrupted by their own death into a cannibalistic wendigo

The Ursuma- plant shifters born from mutated Ghost Wolves, who have their Essence devoured by a poisonous wolfsbane.

boardgame.name: The Book of Laughing Serpents, Volume 8
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Basalt City. The ten thousand hells. The land of demons. Malfeas. Many secrets lie in the churning prison of the gods—from its demons, which hold one hundred and eight thousand courts; to communities of mortals, both human and otherwise; to weapons and arts that are older than the Scarlet Dynasty. The Exalted have long meddled in the affairs of hell, and now the time has come to detail some of the wonders and horrors they have found!

The Book of Laughing Serpents is a series of supplements that will cover the many forms of hell—prehuman nations, mighty demon lords, and forbidden tools and techniques!

The Book of Laughing Serpents, Volume 8 is a multipage PDF that contains six fully statted and skinned demon quick characters (QC) for use in your Exalted 3E games. In this volume you'll find the following:

Demons of the First Circle
Robakzdray, the Typhonic Worms (Including a sorcerous initiation for voluntary infection)
Vadaszok, the Hunting Horrors
Skilotozas, the Screams of the Deep
Duhosbunbak, the Defiant Scapegoats (Including uses for their horns and wool)

Demons of the Second Circle
Vallasbarlang, the Martyr-Making Tiger (Including locations she has marked in Creation)
Kairapu, the Dragon-Feeding Tree

boardgame.name: The Book of Wonders Wanted: Solars
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"The world will never starve for want of wonders, but only for want of wonder."

This is a collection of brand-new Solar Charms. Have you ever wanted your Solar to start a farm? Probably not! But with the Charms in this book, it might start to look appealing! I've put together a set of new powers that focuses on helping your character stand out among the rest.

Use this book if you've ever wanted to start a small business, enact the glorious people's revolution, smash a boulder with a finger, demand to see the manager, fall in love, write a novel, give good advice, give bad advice, give hilarious advice, practice austerities, find people who share your hobbies, get really hammered, fish Kejak straight out of Heaven, or abruptly leave the building.

The Book of Wonders Wanted — if you wonder what wonder you wanted, we want you to wonder what might be in here.

boardgame.name: Bimbo
boardgame.description:
Content of the playing instructions:

The card game of 1000 possibilities

Bimbo is a stimulating and entertaining game.
Bimbo trains quick thinking and sharpens the mind.
Bimbo is easy to play: cheerfulness and serenity come into their own right from the first game.

How to play:
1. Bimbo as a card game for 3 or more people (use 128 cards for more than 3 players)
2. Bimbo as a solitaire game for 1 person
3. Bimbo as a fighting patience for 2 people

Bimbo consists of 64 cards, 21 with capital letters, 41 cards with small letters and two "Bimbo" cards.

Bimbo is published in two editions: single game (64 cards) and double game with red and green back (128 cards)

Personal note:
The word "Bimbo" is commonly known as an insult.
It is unclear why the game was called like this, as it is an abstract game.

boardgame.name: Dawn of Madness: Of Art and Oblivion
boardgame.description: Of Art and Oblivion is a Wanderer expansion featuring Cary James the Actor. This expansion adds a whole new chapter to a Dawn of Madness campaign, complete with its own twisted story.

boardgame.name: Curse of The Necronomicon
boardgame.description:
Curse of the Necronomicon is a trading card game where players take control of the spells and creatures described in the Necronomicon( based on the works of HP Lovecraft, August Derleth, and many others) and compete against each other to see who can hold on to their sanity while driving the other to madness. They do this by summoning creatures and casting spells from the pages of the Necronomicon to drive their opponent to madness.

How To Play:
1. Each player starts with a 35 card deck that they shuffle at the beginning of the game and draw five cards
2. Each player then starts their turn with the draw phase then the summoning phase then the end phase
2(a). during the draw phase the player draws one card from the top of their deck
2(b.) during the summoning phase players may summon up to four creatures at a time on the field and may cast two spells per turn
2(c). during the end phase players may attack the opponent sanity or their creatures and the effect of spells take place
3. A player may take damage to their sanity when a spell is cast on them or a creature attacks them
4. The game ends when one player has run out of sanity and is now mad
Special rule: in order to summon larger creatures such as great old ones or outer gods a sacrifice is needed: for a Great Old One two lesser creatures must be sacrificed and for an Outer God two Great old Ones( or equivalent ) must be sacrificed. To check the classification of creatures and what spells affect them check the keywords.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Escape Room in a Box: The Walking Dead
boardgame.description:
You are a group of survivors in a post-apocalyptic world who have stumbled upon a secured, walled-off community. To gain access, you must prove you have the skills necessary to help lead humanity into a new, golden age. If you fail, you will be eliminated. The stakes are high, and so is the challenge.

Escape Room in a Box: The Walking Dead puts you and your friends into the dangerous world of AMC's The Walking Dead TV show. You and up to seven other players have 90 minutes to solve puzzles, crack codes, and unlock real, physical locks in order to finally open the giant locked door, gain access to the community, and win the game.

The puzzles in this game are non-linear, meaning everyone will always have something to do, just like an in-person escape room. Work together and keep the lines of communication open, and you just might be able to survive this tactile tabletop escape room experience.

--No knowledge of The Walking Dead television series or comics is required to play this game--

-description from designer
boardgame.boardgamefamily: Series: Escape Room in a Box (Mattel)

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

listing.notes: Played once, put it back together in a way that it can be replayed right away.

boardgame.name: Clue: Card Game
boardgame.description:
The Classic Mystery Board Game now has a twist as a fast, fun card game! In this version of the Clue game, players use Evidence cards and Case File cards to gather information and eliminate suspects, rooms, and weapons. It's an exciting strategy game as players ask questions about who did the crime, where it was done, and which weapon was used. Ready for an accusation? The cards under the Crime card must match the player's accusation for them to win the game. If the cards don't match, they lose! This quick-playing card game is a convenient way to let your kids take the Clue game with them when traveling or visiting a friend's house.

—description from the publisher
boardgame.boardgamefamily: Game: Cluedo / Clue (Parker Brothers, et al)

boardgame.name: Ascension: Turzan, Lion of Uzkara
boardgame.description:
Name: Turzan, Lion of Uzkara
Cost: 8 Runes
Text: Lifebound Hero
Draw a card.
This turn, if you play two other lifebound heroes, you win the game.
6 Honor

This card was featured in the movie Good Boys (2019) and was first released as a prize during the Ascension Tactics Kickstarter Campaign. There have been different iterations of this card with varied rune costs, abilities, and honor values.

boardgame.name: Gears of War
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Welcome to a problematic world where everything’s gone to hell in a handbasket!

I'm sure you're used to that by now, so how about a good old-fashioned war of survival against an inhuman force pushing humanity to extinction? A battle of resources, of land, and the right to see who lives on this planet when the dust finally settles. The species that’s the most determined will naturally win, and the losers will be lucky if they make a footnote in the history of Sera.

What? No, I didn't mean Earth. I really mean Sera. You're on a whole new world...

boardgame.name: Gelato
boardgame.description:
In the Gelato game we love to eat ice cream and our goal is to be the first player to get 3 ice cream cards.
Gelato is a game of strategy and opportunity in which we must know how to manage the result of the dice roll to achieve victory.

OBJECTIVE
Be the first to get 3 ice cream cards.

SETUP
Place the 11 ice cream cards on the table, distribute each player 3 tiles of the same color and leave the 3 dice on the table.

HOW TO PLAY:
The youngest player starts. You must roll all 3 dice and be left with only the result of 2 dice (the other discards it).
You must add them and with that result you can take an action.

With the value of the sum of 2 dice you have 3 options:

- Draw a token from your reserve and place it in the first position on the card of that value.
- Advance a token already placed on a card of that value.
- Remove one of his tokens from one of the cards he previously placed and relocate it to position 1 of the card of that value.

HOW TO DRAW A LETTER:
When a player reaches the final position of a card, he takes it for himself. He places it in front of him turned and leaves the used token on it being unused. He will play with one less chip.
If other players 'tokens are found on the card to be lifted, they return to their owners' reserve.

GAME OVER:
The first player to get 3 cards in their possession wins the game.

ADVANCED VERSION
It is played the same as the base game but the 4 effect cards are mixed, the first 2 are taken and placed on the table. The remaining 2 are removed from the game.

These letters have actions. Some are executed immediately and others on the next turn of whoever chose it. A player achieves an effect when one of his pieces is placed in the middle position of a card with its numerical value in white.

At that time you can select one of the 2 visible effects. Then that card must turn it over and the effect of its reverse will be the one that can be chosen in the future.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Bestiary Notebook Set: 8 Mini Notebooks
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This officially licensed 8-notebook boxed set with red foil stamping and spot gloss on the slipcase features some of the most iconic beasts and creatures of Dungeons & Dragons. It's perfect for notetaking and world-building, a must-have gift for D&D players as well as RPG, sci-fi, fantasy, and horror lovers.

This boxed set of 8 pocket-size notebooks pays homage to some of Dungeons & Dragons most beloved beasts and creatures. Each notebook cover features a different monster in a new, modern design, while the interior includes a brief history of each creature. Handpicked to include a mix of fearsome creations and fan favorites, Dungeons and Dragons Bestiary Notebook Set is a must-have collector's item for any D&D fan.

boardgame.name: The Worldbuilder's Journal of Legendary Adventures: 365 Questions to Help You Create Mythical Characters, Storied Worlds, and Unique Campaigns
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

An official Dungeons & Dragons journal featuring 365 writing prompts to help role-players of all levels get their creative juices flowing.

Building something from scratch is exciting, but it can also be a challenge. Within this journal lie 365 prompts to help you start your journey. Every page will steer you to strengthening the details of your world, whether you’re playing within the vast Dungeons & Dragons cosmos or creating a landscape of your own design.

You’ll encounter insightful questions that encourage you to delve deep into the backstories of your characters and their enemies, and what drives them to a life of adventure. You’ll also see prompts that reference D&D myths and legends, some familiar and others more obscure. Answer them as best you can or let them be the spark that starts your journey into the endless realms of D&D lore.

Above all, this guided journal, like D&D itself, is driven by your imagination. There are no wrong answers, paths, or rolls here (though once the game begins there are no guarantees). Nor do you need to be a master storyteller, writer, or artist. You just need to aspire to create and have the courage to build something you may have never before imagined.

boardgame.name: Scene It?: Game Pack – Movie Edition
boardgame.description:
Add to your Scene It? board game with this Game Pack DVD and trivia cards! Hundreds more scenes and images from Hollywood's biggest movies test your knowledge and observation skills. Enjoy all your favourite visual puzzler challengers from the first game plus the extra Zoom Out and Credit Roll categories.

So dim the lights, sit back and get ready for more movies, more stars and more fun!

—description from the publisher
boardgame.boardgameintegration: Scene It?: The DVD Movie Game
Scene It?: The DVD Movie Game

boardgame.name: Campeones de Midgard: Big Box
boardgame.description:
Champions of Midgard is a middleweight, Viking-themed, worker placement game with dice rolling in which players are leaders of Viking clans who have traveled to an embattled Viking harbor town to help defend it against the threat of trolls, draugr, and other mythological Norse beasts. By defeating these epic creatures, players gain glory and the favor of the gods. When the game ends, the player who has earned the most glory earns the title of Jarl and is recognized as a champion of Midgard!

Placing workers allows for the collection of resources and warriors, which players may then send on journeys to neighboring villages or across the sea to defeat monsters and gain the glory they need for victory. Resources are used to carve runes, build ships, and feed your followers. Viking warriors (custom dice) do battle with the myriad enemies the town faces.


This Big Box edition contains the base game, Valhalla and Dark Mountains expansions and KS promos.

Petz: Catz 2

User Summary

This is not to be confused with Petz: Catz 2 for [videogameplatform=4434] and [videogameplatform=4441 Nintendo Wii], since although they share the same cover the PS2/Wii version is an adventure game where you play as a cat, where the DS version is a... Tamagotchi

boardgame.name: Mad Person with a Blue Box - A Troika! Background
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

This is a new background for Troika! Numinous Edition, for an individual who stole a Blue Box of Power and left to travel the spheres. It should be pretty obvious what the inspiration for this background was.

boardgame.name: Alone Against Fear: The Village of the Living Dolls
boardgame.description:
This is a 60-page PDF adventure for Alone Against Fear. Your uncle Phil is missing and you volunteer to help finding him, but this will plunge your character in a maelstrom of horror as you explore Harrowood, the Village of the Living Dolls.

This is a complete adventure that will require two hours or more to complete.

-description from publisher's website

boardgame.name: The Village of the Living Dolls
boardgame.description:
